text: and there we can hear some applause
coming out some of the relatives coming
out with Liverpool scarves on we just
saw and there perhaps you can see
hugging
relatives as we heard that they were in
court hugging each other and now outside
the coroner's court you can see the
immediate reaction of some of the
relatives who heard that's answer to
question six of unlawful killing a
decision by the jury of six women and
three men that it was unlawful killing
of the 96 Liverpool fans who went to
that football match that FA Cup
semi-final on April the 15th 1989 and
more fan more relatives more of the
bereaved coming out we can just see over
my left shoulder and more hugging more
chairs more applause as indeed there was
in courts we heard that hallelujah was
shouted out inside the courtroom when
the jury returns that decision that
conclusion to question six that the 96
fans that day were unlawfully kills and
to reach that conclusion as we were
hearing from Clive Coleman the jury had
to accept that it was gross negligence
and a failure in the duty of care by the
match commander on the day Chief
Superintendent David duckenfield who was
in the control box there were other
senior officers out at the turnstiles at
the perimeter of the pitch as well but
he was in overall charge and it was he
who made the fateful decision at 2:52 on
April the 15th to open exit gates II as
he had been asked to do by
superintendent Roach and Marshall who
was outside at the turnstiles trying to
deal with a crush at the turnstiles at
the Liverpool end
and when he made that fateful decision
by his own account David duckenfield he
froze his mind went blank it has been
described as a blunder of the first
magnitude to allow another 2000
Liverpool fans to come into the Leppings
Lane ends and to join into the pens and
the Leppings Lane and that were already
as was described in the coroner's court
as heaving and the fans who were there
described how it had tightened like a
vise as the crush began at the Leppings
Lane and the decision not only to open
gate see but then to allow the fans who
came in through gate see through the
tunnel and straight into those central
pens pens three and four where the crush
happened not to direct them away from
that tunnel and that is the decision
then by the jury that's there for those
reasons that was gross negligence by the
match commander and he did have a duty
of care and he did breach that duty of
care and that that breach of contributed
directly to the deaths of the 96 fans
